ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: an understanding of influence across the Greek literary tradition; an understanding of how the literature we have survived to us; literary appreciation of motifs etc; ability to read most Greek dialects

I developed better Greek reading skills through exposure to various genres. I also learned general information, contextual and historical, about the various authors and genres. Overall I have a better grasp of the bigger picture of epic and lyric poetry and learned through this course how to synthesize the big picture with the little details.
My Greek improved, and I learned more about Greek literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The greatest strength of this course is that we get through a significant amount of Greek in a very short time. One thing that could help is if we more systematically tackled the background information for each poet (perhaps grouping each poet by date or by genre/style/content for the lyric poets would help).
I think that the course is well-designed.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course because it helps one improve Greek and gain some familiarity with multiple authors and periods.
